chapter.title: Performance Best Practices
chapter.para: This chapter covers a number of jQuery and JavaScript best practices, in no particular order. Many of the best practices in this chapter are based on the jQuery Anti-Patterns for Performance presentation by Paul Irish.

sect1.title: Cache length during loops
sect1.para: In a for loop, don't access the length property of an array every time; cache it beforehand.

sect1.title: Append new content outside of a loop
sect1.para: Touching the DOM comes at a cost; if you're adding a lot of elements to the DOM, do it all at once, not one at a time.

sect1.title: Keep things DRY
sect1.para: Don't repeat yourself; if you're repeating yourself, you're doing it wrong.

sect1.title: Beware anonymous functions
sect1.para: Anonymous functions bound everywhere are a pain. They're difficult to debug, maintain, test, or reuse. Instead, use an object literal to organize and name your handlers and callbacks.

sect1.title: Optimize Selectors
sect1.para: Selector optimization is less important than it used to be, as more browsers implement document.querySelectorAll() and the burden of selection shifts from jQuery to the browser. However, there are still some tips to keep in midn.

sect2.title: ID-Based Selectors
sect2.para: Beginning your selector with an ID is always best.

The $.fn.find approach is faster because the first selection is handled without going through the Sizzle selector engine — ID-only selections are handled using document.getElementById(), which is extremely fast because it is native to the browser.

sect2.title: Specificity
sect2.para: Be specific on the right-hand side of your selector, and less specific on the left.
Use tag.class if possible on your right-most selector, and just tag or just .class on the left.
A "flatter" DOM also helps improve selector performance, as the selector engine has fewer layers to traverse when looking for an element.

sect2.title: Avoid the Universal Selector
sect2.para: Selections that specify or imply that a match could be found anywhere can be very slow.
sect2.programlisting:
$('.buttons > *'); // extremely expensive $('.buttons').children(); // much better
$('.gender :radio'); // implied universal selection $('.gender *:radio'); // same thing, explicit now $('.gender input:radio'); // much better

sect1.title: Use Event Delegation
sect1.para: Event delegation allows you to bind an event handler to one container element (for example, an unordered list) instead of multiple contained elements (for example, list items). jQuery makes this easy with $.fn.live and $.fn.delegate. Where possible, you should use $.fn.delegate instead of $.fn.live, as it eliminates the need for an unnecessary selection, and its explicit context (vs. $.fn.live's context of document) reduces overhead by approximately 80%.
In addition to performance benefits, event delegation also allows you to add new contained elements to your page without having to re-bind the event handlers for them as they're added.

sect1.title: Detach Elements to Work With Them
sect1.para: The DOM is slow; you want to avoid manipulating it as much as possible. jQuery introduced $.fn.detach in version 1.4 to help address this issue, allowing you to remove an element from the DOM while you work with it.

sect1.title: Use Stylesheets for Changing CSS on Many Elements
sect1.para: If you're changing the CSS of more than 20 elements using $.fn.css, consider adding a style tag to the page instead for a nearly 60% increase in speed.

sect1.title: Use $.data Instead of $.fn.data
sect1.para: Using $.data on a DOM element instead of calling $.fn.data on a jQuery selection can be up to 10 times faster. Be sure you understand the difference between a DOM element and a jQuery selection before doing this, though.

sect1.title: Don't Act on Absent Elements
sect1.para: jQuery won't tell you if you're trying to run a whole lot of code on an empty selection — it will proceed as though nothing's wrong. It's up to you to verify that your selection contains some elements.
This guidance is especially applicable for jQuery UI widgets, which have a lot of overhead even when the selection doesn't contain elements.

sect1.title: Variable Definition
sect1.para: Variables can be defined in one statement instead of several.
In self-executing functions, variable definition can be skipped all together.

sect1.title: Conditionals
Don't Treat jQuery as a Black Box
sect1.para: Use the source as your documentation — bookmark http://bit.ly/jqsource and refer to it often.
